title: VocalNet: Speech LLM with Multi-Token Prediction for Faster and High-Quality Generation
author: Yuhao Wang (Shanghai Jiao Tong University), Heyang Liu (Shanghai Jiao Tong University), Ziyang Cheng (Wuhan University), Ronghua Wu (Ant Group), Qunshan Gu (Ant Group), Yanfeng Wang (Shanghai Jiao Tong University), Yu Wang (Shanghai Jiao Tong University), ...
relevance_why: The paper addresses multi-token prediction in speech models, which could enhance audio generation tasks in Haohe Liu's work, particularly in improving real-time speech synthesis and audio quality.
background: The paper explores real-time voice interaction systems that generate speech from text, utilizing an innovative architecture for efficient speech modeling with Multi-Token Prediction.
contribution: This paper introduces VocalNet, a series of speech interaction models utilizing Multi-Token Prediction to accelerate speech generation while maintaining high-quality outputs.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods predominantly relied on Next-Token Prediction, which often led to slower generation times and error accumulation due to their autoregressive nature.
technical_comparison.novelty: VocalNet implements Multi-Token Prediction, enabling parallel generation of multiple speech tokens, thus reducing latency and enhancing the quality of generated speech.

key_innovation: The unique aspect of VocalNet is its focus on Multi-Token Prediction, allowing it to capture complex speech structures more effectively by predicting multiple tokens simultaneously.
real_world_impact: This innovation can significantly improve user experiences in voice-activated applications and conversational agents through faster and more natural speech responses.
limitations: The model depends on specific training datasets which may restrict generalizability to different speech applications.

new_terms.Multi-Token Prediction: **Multi-Token Prediction** is a method that allows models to predict multiple output tokens simultaneously, rather than sequentially as in traditional autoregressive approaches, improving efficiency and quality in audio generation.

open_sourcing: The authors plan to open-source all model weights, inference code, training data, and framework implementations upon publication.
